title: Financial Services Text Face?
content:
hi,

i’m doing a couple of spreads in a magazine as an extra promotional section for selected financial services providers in the LA area…i’m looking for some opinions on what a good text face might be?

i’m leaning more towards sans serif but serif is not out of the question…

right now, there’s some ITC Franklin Gothic small giving address/phone number etc, but that is flexible depending on the textface chosen….opinions would be greatly appreciated

thanks

w|m
author: Will Miller

comments.content:
If you’re setting tables of financial data and blocks of text, a face with lining and oldstyle numerals is probably a good bet. That’s more common in serif faces, but is becoming more common in contemporary sans.

Without knowing more, that’s as specific as I can get.

a little more….

it’s not going to use tables or speak on financial data, for the most part, it’s mostly a piece (6 to 12 pages) that’s highlighting certain “wealth management firms”

i guess it’s a little bit about the people, the office, their specialties, some of their past clients…

i’m just having a hard time zeroing in on a text face that conveys assurance, confidence and longevity in dealing with this subject

w|m

I would think [Giacomo](http://web.archive.org/web/20050825013538/http:/terminaldesign.com/retail_specimen.php?ID=1176&viewFam=1), a sweet sans by Terminal Design, might be ideal. It has tabular lining figures as well as proportional oldstyle figures, and looks great in a magazine.

Edit: I just missed your second post. In that light, here are two more that might fit the bill: [Apex Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20050825013538/http:/thirstype.com/fonts.php?font=ApexSans) from Thirstype, and [Section](http://web.archive.org/web/20050825013538/http:/lux.thirstype.com/fonts.php?font=Section) from Lux Typographics. To me, each conveys strength but with a modern flair.

yeah, these are great! unfortunately we lack the licenses for all of those but it’s a great starting point. giacomo fits the bill nicely i think

w|m

Considering the audience, I would think a serif font would be more appropriate. They are easier to read, and it’s what the audience is used to. The Wall Street Journal’s text font is a variation of Scotch, so Scotch Roman may work…  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/scotch/](http://web.archive.org/web/20050825013538/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/scotch/)

Modern extended is also nice (imho).  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/urw/modern-extended/](http://web.archive.org/web/20050825013538/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/urw/modern-extended/)

There’s my 2¢,

Cheers!
